title: Introduction to Data Science Daily Overview: Unit 1 Abstract
body: Unit 1 of "Introduction to Data Science" provides a comprehensive 35-day curriculum structured into three major themes: "Data Are All Around," "Visualizing Data," and "Would You Look at the Time?" The unit culminates in an "End of Unit Project." Students will explore fundamental data science concepts, beginning with defining data and consumer privacy, understanding data organization, and engaging with the data cycle. Practical skills include organizing and collecting data, developing statistical questions, and recognizing variability. The unit then transitions into data visualization, covering dotplots, histograms, and multi-variable plots, with an introduction to RStudio for data analysis and visualization. Finally, students will delve into categorical associations, two-way tables, and data cleaning techniques using real-world data from "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" and "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use." Practicums and an end-of-unit project reinforce the data cycle and claim evaluation.

title: Unit 1 Theme 1: Data Are All Around - Overview
body: The first theme of Unit 1, "Data Are All Around," spans seven days (Days 1-7) and introduces fundamental concepts in data science. This segment focuses on defining data, understanding consumer privacy, and exploring methods for organizing and collecting data. Key topics include data structures like rows, columns, and variables. Students will also learn about the data cycle and how to formulate statistical questions, while recognizing the importance of variability. This theme sets the stage for practical data exploration and includes the start of the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" for initial data collection.

title: Unit 1 Lessons 1-3: Fundamentals of Data
body: Unit 1 begins with foundational data concepts across Unit 1 Lesson 1 to Unit 1 Lesson 3. Unit 1 Lesson 1: Data Trails (Day 1, Page 24) introduces the definition of data and discussions on consumer privacy. Following this, Unit 1 Lesson 2: Stick Figures (Day 2, Page 26) covers methods for organizing and collecting data. Unit 1 Lesson 3: Data Structures (Day 3, Page 28) delves deeper into organizing data, explaining concepts such as rows, columns, and variables. These lessons establish the basic understanding required for subsequent data science topics in Unit 1, emphasizing the fundamental structure of datasets.

title: Unit 1 Lessons 4-7: The Data Cycle and Initial Data Collection
body: Days 4-7 of Unit 1 focus on the data cycle, statistical questions, and initial data collection. Unit 1 Lesson 4: The Data Cycle (Day 4, Page 30) introduces the comprehensive data cycle and the formulation of statistical questions. Building on this, Unit 1 Lesson 5: So Many Questions (Day 5, Page 35) further explores statistical questions and the concept of variability. The practical application begins with Unit 1 Lesson 6: What Do I Eat? (Day 6, Page 39), which integrates the data cycle and data collection, launching the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits." Unit 1 Lesson 7: Setting the Stage (Day 7, Page 42) focuses on participatory sensing as a data collection method within the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data," marking the start of the data collection window.

title: Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits - Introduction and Initial Data Collection
body: The "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" is a key practical component of Unit 1, initiated on Day 6 with Unit 1 Lesson 6: What Do I Eat? (Page 39). This lesson focuses on the data cycle and collecting data related to food habits. The data collection window formally begins on Day 7, facilitated by Unit 1 Lesson 7: Setting the Stage, which introduces participatory sensing as a method for data collection (Page 42). This campaign's data ('Food Habits – data') is used extensively in subsequent lessons and labs under the "Visualizing Data" theme, allowing students to analyze real-world data, with its data collection window concluding on Day 15.

title: Unit 1 Theme 2: Visualizing Data - Overview
body: Spanning 14 days (Days 8-21), the "Visualizing Data" theme in Unit 1 is dedicated to teaching students how to effectively represent and analyze data. This theme covers a range of visualization techniques, starting with basic plots like dotplots and histograms, and advancing to multi-variable plots. Students will learn to interpret data characteristics such as minimum, maximum, frequency, typical value, center, shape, and spread. A significant part of this theme involves introducing the RStudio environment, enabling students to apply coding for data analysis, import datasets, and create various graphs. The "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data" is extensively used throughout this theme, with its data collection window ending on Day 15. The theme includes labs and culminates in a practicum focusing on the data cycle and variability using the "Food Habits" data.

title: Unit 1 Lessons 8-11: Fundamental Data Visualization Techniques
body: Days 8 through 11 of Unit 1 focus on fundamental data visualization techniques, primarily utilizing data from the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data." Unit 1 Lesson 8: Tangible Plots (Day 8, Page 48) introduces dotplots, minimum/maximum values, and frequency. Unit 1 Lesson 9: What Is Typical? (Day 9, Page 52) delves into concepts of typical value and data center. Unit 1 Lesson 10: Making Histograms (Day 10, Page 55) teaches how to construct histograms and the importance of bin widths. Finally, Unit 1 Lesson 11: What Shape Are You In? (Day 11, Page 58) explores the shape, center, and spread of data distributions. These lessons provide the groundwork for understanding and interpreting single-variable data visualizations.

title: Unit 1 Lessons 12-14: Introduction to RStudio and Data Exploration
body: Days 12-14 of Unit 1 mark the introduction to computational data analysis using RStudio. Unit 1 Lesson 12: Exploring Food Habits (Day 12, Page 60) provides an initial look at single and multi-variable plots, often using "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data." Unit 1 Lesson 13: RStudio Basics (Day 13, Page 62) offers a comprehensive introduction to the RStudio environment, a critical skill for the entire course. This is immediately followed by Unit 1 Lab 1A: Data, Code & RStudio (Day 14, Page 65), which reinforces RStudio basics and continues to leverage the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data." The data collection window for "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" concludes on Day 15.

title: Unit 1 Labs 1B-1C: Advanced Visualization and Data Importing in RStudio
body: Building on the RStudio introduction, Unit 1 Lab 1B: Get the Picture? (Day 15, Page 68) explores variable types, bar graphs, and histograms, further applying RStudio skills to "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data." The data collection window for "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" officially ends on Day 15. Subsequently, Unit 1 Lab 1C: Export, Upload, Import (Day 16, Page 71) teaches the crucial process of importing data into RStudio, an essential skill for any data scientist. These labs consolidate hands-on experience with RStudio for more advanced data visualization and data management.

title: Unit 1 Lesson 14 & Labs 1D-1E: Exploring Multi-Variable Relationships
body: Expanding on visualization techniques, Unit 1 Lesson 14: Variables, Variables, Variables (Day 17, Page 75) delves into multi-variable plots, demonstrating how to visualize relationships between multiple datasets. This concept is reinforced in Unit 1 Lab 1D: Zooming Through Data (Day 18, Page 79), which introduces subsetting data for focused analysis. The exploration of relationships continues with Unit 1 Lab 1E: What’s the Relationship? (Day 19, Page 83), further practicing multi-variable plots. These lessons and labs equip students with the ability to analyze more complex data relationships and prepare them for comprehensive data interpretation.

title: Unit 1 Practicum: The Data Cycle & My Food Habits
body: The "Visualizing Data" theme culminates with Unit 1 Practicum: The Data Cycle & My Food Habits (Day 20, Page 86) and subsequent Practicum Presentations (Day 21). This practicum serves as a summative assessment, challenging students to apply their understanding of the data cycle and variability using the collected "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" data. Students will interpret their analyses and present their findings, demonstrating their proficiency in data collection, visualization, and interpretation within the context of the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits." These activities reinforce the comprehensive data science process learned throughout the unit.

title: Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits - Conclusion and Analysis
body: The "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits," which began with data collection from Day 7 (Unit 1 Lesson 7) to Day 15, is a central element for learning data analysis and visualization in Unit 1. Data collected through participatory sensing is extensively used in various lessons and labs, including Unit 1 Lesson 8 through Unit 1 Lesson 12, Unit 1 Lab 1A, and Unit 1 Lab 1B. The campaign culminates with Unit 1 Practicum: The Data Cycle & My Food Habits on Day 20 (Page 86) and its presentations on Day 21, where students apply their knowledge of the data cycle and variability to the collected "Food Habits" data, demonstrating comprehensive understanding of the data science workflow.

title: Unit 1 Theme 3: Would You Look at the Time? - Overview
body: The third major theme of Unit 1, "Would You Look at the Time?", spans nine days (Days 22-30) and focuses on analyzing categorical data, specifically time use. This theme introduces students to evaluating claims based on data and delves into advanced data cleaning techniques. Key statistical concepts covered include joint relative frequencies, marginal relative frequencies, and conditional relative frequencies, often presented through 2-way tables. The "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use – data" is central to this theme, providing a dataset for practical application in labs and a practicum focused on interpreting plots and statistical questions related to "Time Use" and "Teen Depression." The theme concludes with a synthesis lab applying the data cycle.

title: Unit 1 Lessons 15 & Lab 1F: Evaluating Claims and Data Cleaning
body: Days 22 and 23 of Unit 1 introduce critical skills in data evaluation and preparation. Unit 1 Lesson 15: Americans’ Time on Task (Day 22, Page 89) focuses on evaluating claims, using data from the "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use – data." The data collection window for "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use" also begins on Day 22. This is followed by Unit 1 Lab 1F: A Diamond In the Rough (Day 23, Page 94), which teaches essential data cleaning techniques, including cleaning names, categories, and strings, again using "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use – data." These activities prepare students for robust analysis by ensuring data quality and critical assessment of information.

title: Unit 1 Lessons 16-17 & Lab 1G: Categorical Associations and Two-Way Tables
body: Days 24 through 26 of Unit 1 concentrate on analyzing categorical associations using two-way tables, leveraging data from the "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use – data." Unit 1 Lesson 16: Categorical Associations (Day 24, Page 99) introduces joint relative frequencies in 2-way tables. Building on this, Unit 1 Lesson 17: Interpreting Two-Way Tables (Day 25, Page 101) covers marginal and conditional relative frequencies, providing deeper insights into relationships within categorical data. Unit 1 Lab 1G: What’s the FREQ? (Day 26, Page 106) offers hands-on practice with 2-way tables and tallying, reinforcing these concepts. The data collection window for "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use" concludes on Day 26.

title: Unit 1 Practicum 2 & Lab 1H: Time Use Analysis and Synthesis
body: The "Would You Look at the Time?" theme concludes with a practicum and a synthesis lab. Unit 1 Practicum: Teen Depression (Day 27, Page 109) utilizes "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use" data to address statistical questions and interpret plots related to teen depression. Following this, Practicum Presentations on Day 28 allow students to share their analyses. The unit wraps up with Unit 1 Lab 1H: Our Time (Days 29-30, Page 111), which provides a comprehensive application of the data cycle and synthesizes the skills learned throughout the unit, particularly in data cleaning, categorical analysis, and interpretation of findings. These activities emphasize interpreting data and presenting findings effectively.

title: Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use - Data Collection and Analysis
body: The "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use – data" is a significant data source for the "Would You Look at the Time?" theme in Unit 1. The data collection window for this campaign begins on Day 22, coinciding with Unit 1 Lesson 15: Americans’ Time on Task (Page 89), which focuses on evaluating claims. Data cleaning (Unit 1 Lab 1F, Page 94) and analysis using 2-way tables (Unit 1 Lesson 16, Unit 1 Lesson 17, Unit 1 Lab 1G, Pages 99-106) are central to utilizing this dataset. The data collection window ends on Day 26. The campaign's data is then applied in Unit 1 Practicum: Teen Depression (Day 27, Page 109), where students address statistical questions and interpret plots, reinforcing their analytical skills learned during the "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use" engagement.

title: Unit 1 End of Unit Project: Evaluating Claims from the Media
body: The culmination of Unit 1 is the "End of Unit 1 Project: Evaluating Claims from the Media," scheduled for Days 31-35 (Page 112). This five-day project requires students to apply their comprehensive understanding of the data cycle. It challenges them to critically evaluate claims presented in various media sources, using the data analysis and visualization skills acquired throughout the unit. This project serves as a capstone experience, allowing students to demonstrate their ability to apply data science principles to real-world scenarios and effectively communicate their findings and insights.

title: The Data Cycle in Unit 1: From Questions to Synthesis
body: The concept of the data cycle is a foundational element woven throughout Unit 1 of the "Introduction to Data Science" course. It is formally introduced in Unit 1 Lesson 4: The Data Cycle (Day 4, Page 30), where students learn to formulate statistical questions. Practical application begins with Unit 1 Lesson 6: What Do I Eat? (Day 6, Page 39), which involves collecting data for the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits." The cycle continues through visualization, analysis, and interpretation, as demonstrated in Unit 1 Practicum: The Data Cycle & My Food Habits (Day 20, Page 86). Further reinforcement comes in Unit 1 Lab 1H: Our Time (Days 29-30, Page 111), which requires synthesis using the data cycle. The entire Unit 1 End of Unit 1 Project: Evaluating Claims from the Media (Days 31-35, Page 112) is centered on applying the data cycle to critically assess real-world claims, showcasing its comprehensive importance in data science.

title: RStudio Integration in Unit 1: From Basics to Advanced Labs
body: RStudio is a crucial tool introduced in Unit 1 for practical data analysis and visualization. The journey begins with Unit 1 Lesson 13: RStudio Basics (Day 13, Page 62), providing students with their initial setup and understanding of the environment. This foundational lesson is immediately followed by hands-on experience in Unit 1 Lab 1A: Data, Code & RStudio (Day 14, Page 65), which reinforces basic RStudio functionalities using the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data." Further RStudio proficiency is developed in Unit 1 Lab 1B: Get the Picture? (Day 15, Page 68), where students use RStudio for creating bar graphs and histograms, and Unit 1 Lab 1C: Export, Upload, Import (Day 16, Page 71), which focuses on importing data. These labs ensure students gain practical coding skills for managing, visualizing, and analyzing data effectively within the RStudio environment.

title: Statistical Questions and Variability in Unit 1
body: Formulating statistical questions and understanding variability are core competencies developed early in Unit 1. Unit 1 Lesson 4: The Data Cycle (Day 4, Page 30) introduces students to crafting effective statistical questions as part of the data cycle. This concept is further explored in Unit 1 Lesson 5: So Many Questions (Day 5, Page 35), which explicitly addresses statistical questions and the critical concept of variability in data. These principles are then applied in practical scenarios, such as Unit 1 Practicum: The Data Cycle & My Food Habits (Day 20, Page 86) and its presentations, where students analyze variability within the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits" data. Similarly, Unit 1 Practicum: Teen Depression (Day 27, Page 109) challenges students to interpret plots and statistical questions based on "Unit 1 Campaign: Time Use" data, reinforcing the importance of these concepts for drawing meaningful conclusions.

title: Data Organization, Structures, and Variables in Unit 1
body: Unit 1 places a strong emphasis on understanding how data is organized and structured. After defining data in Unit 1 Lesson 1: Data Trails (Day 1, Page 24), Unit 1 Lesson 2: Stick Figures (Day 2, Page 26) introduces initial methods for organizing and collecting data. A deeper dive into data structures occurs in Unit 1 Lesson 3: Data Structures (Day 3, Page 28), which covers essential concepts such as rows and columns, and the definition of variables. These foundational lessons are crucial for preparing students to work with datasets, leading into Unit 1 Lesson 14: Variables, Variables, Variables (Day 17, Page 75), which explores multi-variable plots, and Unit 1 Lab 1B: Get the Picture? (Day 15, Page 68), which discusses different variable types in the context of visualization using the "Unit 1 Campaign: Food Habits – data".
